title: Using Strong Triadic Closure to Characterize Ties in Social Networks

author: Stavros Sintos, Department of Computer Science, University of Ioannina

segmentation: Hello, my name is Stavros Windows and this is joint work with Professor Panagiotis Apparels from University of UN in Greece which are the subject of our paper is the characterization of ties in social networks using the strong triadic closure.
There is a final episode of South Park where Stan reluctantly joins Facebook to end up with a million friends, most of whom he does not really know.
This is actually a real problem in online social networks.
The social circle of an average user, of course, contains some true friends, but also contains some distant relatives or some old forgotten high school classmates.
So it is difficult to find who are the true friends in a social network.
Um?

And this is a very important problem because there are applications such as online marketing, phrasing, suggestion, algorithms, or simply the sociological analysis of networks where knowing the strength and the nature of online relationship is significant importance.
In our work, we address this problem.

We will show how we characterize social ties using kaleidagraph structure and more specifically, we will see how we can characterize network ties are strong or weak using the strong triadic closure property.
This is a concept originating from psychology that dates back to 1973 when it was introduced by Granovetter in his Seminole paper the strength of weak ties.
The property is discussed in detail in the recent book of Easley and Kleinberg, who use the strong triadic closure property in order to understand, to understand the strength of weak ties.
The road map of the presentation is the following.
First, I'll give you the problem definition.
Then I will discuss some algorithms for these problems.
After that I will present some experiments or real data and finally we will have some concluding remarks.
First, let me give you some intuition of the strong triadic closure property.
Consider Stan, who is friend with Eric and Kyle.
If Stan has strong relationships with both of them guys, then strong triadic closure says that there must be.

Connection between Eric and Kyle and this is something that makes sense, because if Stan is very good friends with both of them, then it must be the case that Eric and Kyle must have at least met each other.
Maybe their connection is a weak one, but we just.
Need a link between them on the other.
If there is no edge between Eric and Kyle, then STC says that one of the two relationships of Stan must be weak.
For example, the relationship between Stan and Kyle, and note that for the following we represent the weekends with blue color and strong edges with red color.
I will now generalize the idea of strong triadic closure in graphs.
First, consider relabeling convenience of a graph are strong or weak.
We say that the labeling satisfies the strong triadic closure property if there is no open triangle with both of its edges are strong.
For example, here if you examine these labeling, it satisfies the SDC property, cause every open triangle contains at least one week ads.
On the other hand, if we.
Make the AIDS AB strong strong tie then this labeling violates this property because now there are actually three open triangles with both of their ages.
How strong the triangles ABC BA&BAD?
Now a natural question is how can we label ties of social networks as strong or weak so that the strong triadic closure property holds?
A trivial solution to that problem is to characterize every edge week.
However, we believe that creating strong relationships is what motivates people in order to join and engage with the social network.
So we consider the following problem.

Find the labeling convenience of a graph as strong or weak that satisfies the STC property and maximizes the number of strong edges, and we call that problem Max SD seem equivalently we define the ministry problem where we aim to minimize the number of weekends.
Note that the optimal solution for these two problems is obviously the same.
I'm.
Unfortunately, as you would expect, Max SEC and Minister problems are NP hard and we prove that by doing a reduction from the problem of finding the maximum click in a graph to the Max STC problem.
For more details you can see our page.
Since our problems are NP hard, we are look for look for approximate solutions.
Because of the.
Of the reduction of Max clique problem, we can show that Max is disease, heart approximate.
On the other hand there there is a two approximation algorithm for the meanest easy problem.
The intuition for this approximation algorithm is the following.
First, recall that we cannot have an open triangle with two strong edges, so for every open triangle there must be at least one week ads, and we say that this week adds coverage.
This triangle, for example, if you see this sub graph which consists of two open triangles, if we make the HBC week, then this week ads covers both of the open triangles.
So using the idea of covering open triangles.
With weak edges we will map the meanest easy problem to a coverage problem, and more specifically to the minimum vertex cover problem.

Let me give you the let me remind you the definition of a minimum vertex cover problem of vertex cover in a graph is a subset of vertices C such that for every edge at least one endpoint belongs to see and for the minimum vertex cover problem we ask for a vertex cover with the smallest number of vertices.
Now, in order to map the Minister problem to them in vertex cover problem, we create the dual graph D using our input graph G and we construct the dual graph D as follows.
For every edge in our input graph gym.
For example, for the edge CD we create a node in the dual graph and two nodes in the dual graph are connected.
For example, the node.

Graph participate in an open triangle because there is no edge between nodes D&F.
Now finding vertex cover in our in our dual graph means that every edge in the dual graph for every edge in our dual graph there is a node in the vertex cover that covers it.

Then minimum vertex cover consists of the blue nodes.
Now we can map a solution for the minimum vertex cover problem in our dual graph deemed to a solution for manesty problem in our input graph G by characterizing the corresponding gauges as we can.
The remaining are strong and at the end of that process all of the Open Triangle report graph are covered.

The good news is that for them in vertex cover problem there are known approximation algorithms with guarantee approximation factors, so we can use these algorithms in order to approximate the solution of our ministry problem.
The first algorithm produces a maximal matching.
A maximum matching is a collection of nonadjacent edges of the graph where no additional edges can be added, and this algorithm has a constant approximation factor equals to two.
The second algorithm is a simple approach is a simple greedy algorithm.
Which at every step greedily select the vertex of covers the most uncovered edges, and this algorithm has an approximation ratio log.
And then and then, given a vertex cover for the dual graph, we characterize the corresponding edges in our input graph D as we can.
The remaining are strong.
I will now present an experimental evaluation that we conduct in real datasets.

The overall goal of our experiments is to check if there is a if our labeling has any practical utility, that is, if the labels that we assigned correspond to an empirical notion of strength and weakness.
For our experiment we use five datasets.
Actors and authors are collaboration networks between movie actors and authors, respectively.

Strengths here represent the amount of common activity between two nodes.
For example, in actors data set is the number of common movies between two actors.
Ideally we want them in strength of strong edges to be higher than the strength of weak edges, and this is actually the case for all of our data sets.
We also found rank the details that the differences between strong and weak edges are statistically significant.
Now the frequency of common activity is obviously a strong indicator of tie strength, but it also may be an artifact of the general frequent activity.
For example, two researchers may have a lot of papers together because they have many papers in general.

Note here that we don't present the results for Lemons are able data set 'cause we don't have the information about the set of chapters that the character appears.

For the second set of experiments, we want to see if the labeling that we obtain validates the idea of the strength of weak ties Granovetter in his Seminole Paper, the strength of weak ties observed that people tend to learn information leading to new jobs through acquaintances.
That is the weak relationships rather rather than close friends that is strong relationships easily in Kleinberg, explained that using a graph theoretic formalization they view the social network.

As partitioned into different communities, where each community has access to different information and they claim that acquaintances act as bridges between different communities and they can give access to new information.
On the other hand, close friends, most of them belong to the same group of people and they cannot give access to different sources of information.
In this set of experiments, we want to see if our labeling agrees with the hypothesis official in Kleinburg.

Amazon Books, which consist of some books about US politics.
Here we have three communities depending on the political view of each book.

For the other regional, in order to measure that, we define the recall of weaken the precision of strong edges, the recall of which is the fraction of Inter community edges that are labeled weak, and the precision of strong is the fraction of strong edges that are intracommunity edges.

Ideally, we want these values to be close to one and in the table you can see the results for the Karate Club and Amazon Books datasets for the Karate Club we have a perfect precision and a perfect recall equals two and one for the Amazon book data set we have precision of strong edges.
I close to 80% and the recall of weak edges almost 70%.

You can see that all of the edges between the two communities are we control of strong edges are confined to integral to intercommunal.

Of course, yeah there is a lot of work in characterizing tie strength.
Here is just a short link list of some indicative papers.
The main difference between these papers and our work is that we use only the graph structure and the strong triadic closure property, and no additional attributes of the node, sort of the edges.
In order to characterize dies.
And for the conclusion, we show that using kaleidagraph structure and the idea of strong triadic closure, we can characterize ties in social network as strong or weak.
In our project we also discuss some extensions and variations of the STC property, for example STC with heads, additions or STC with multiple strong edge types.
And now for the future we know that STC is a strong property, so we want to consider some more relaxed and the software version of it.
And we would like to study further the case of more than one strong types.
Thank you very much.
